opener-hed: We asked thousands of people whether they recognized hit songs from the ’90s, such as Wannabe and No Scrubs, ordering the results by birth year.
opener-subhed: Which song is more likely to be recognized by future generations?

intro-no-diggity.text: It’s an important moment for ’90s music. As with prior decades, today’s teens are experiencing music that they didn’t grow up with, and we can finally start asking them: what do you recognize from ’90s?

Their responses help us understand how future generations will characterize the decade—what’s remembered (and valued) from ’90s culture. For example, I always believed “No Diggity” by Blackstreet would be a ’90s standard, uniting parents and teens at weddings and Bar Mitzvahs of the 2050s.
To answer this question, we’ll use 2 million data points that I collected via a music quiz, which asked whether readers recognized thousands of songs charting on the Billboard Hot 100.

no-diggity-hed: Here's how well people know “No Diggity.”
chart-text-subhed-no-diggity: Percent of people who recognize a clip of “No Diggity,” by birth year

no-diggity-the-sign.text: Just as Sinatra, Elvis, and Chuck Berry are emblematic of the ’50s, this data helps us make  similar judgements of what might be included in the ’90s canon. These will be the artists and songs that Gen Z and beyond seem to recognize (and value) among all the musical output from the decade.

First, it’s important to understand the general trends in the data. “No Diggity” knowledge peaks among people born in 1985, who were 13 years-old when the track debuted in 1998. We also see a slow drop off among people who were not around when “No Diggity” was in its prime, individuals who were 5 years-old and younger (or not born yet) in 1998.
That drop-off rate between generations—in this case, Millennials to Gen Z—is one indicator for whether “No Diggity” is surviving the test of time.

To make this a bit easier to read, we’ll chart the person’s age at release, rather than birth year. For songs to be passed to down, generation to generation, we’d expect a slower decay rate, evidence that it’s remaining part of the collective memory.
Let’s look at another example from the mid-nineties: “The Sign” by Ace of Base .

chart-text-hed-ace-of-base: Similar to “No Diggity,” notice the decline in The Sign knowledge among people who were 5 years-old when it was released in 1993
chart-text-subhed-ace-of-base: Recognition of “The Sign” by age at the time of its release

scroll-intro.text: For readers in their teens, only half of them recognized “The Sign.” The trend here is that music has a natural half-life. Find someone 10-15 years your junior, and the likelihood that they’ll know your childhood music references is lower than you think.
How much lower? An easy way to see this is by charting songs that every Millennial knows.

chart-text-hed-scroll: This is an average of songs that were recognized by over 90% of people who were 13 to 15 years-old when the song debuted—i.e., the Popular Average.

intro-mean.text: Song knowledge erodes with each passing year. This is why I shouldn’t be shocked that my Gen Z colleague has never heard “The Sign,” or that teens are filming themselves listening to “Bohemian Rhapsody” for the first time. This is a normal part of the music aging process.

If you take any present-day hit that’s culturally pervasive, such as “Old Town Road” or “Despacito,” we’d expect that someone born today, in 2020, will probably not recognize it twenty years from now. In short, there’s a good chance they’ll interpret your karaoking of Lizzo, Drake, or Jonas Brothers in 2040 as an obscure act.
An especially sobering example of this decay is “Wild Wild West” by Will Smith .

wild-west-hed: These are the Millennial hits that are fading at an accelerated rate among Gen Z.
wild-west-sub: Songs with lower than expected recognition

popular.text: In 1999, “Wild Wild West” was the song of the summer. Yet it is fading far faster than any other ’90s hit with comparable starting popularity. Twenty years ago, it was inescapable. Maybe Millennials are too sick, even for nostalgia rotation. Perhaps it wasn’t even that great of a song to begin with, artificially inflated by Smith’s celebrity and cross-promotion with the film, Wild Wild West.

“Quit Playing Games” is Backstreet Boy’s fastest decaying hit (“Everybody” is the opposite, known by 97% of Millennials and 86% of Gen Z). I’m not sure where a love ballad like “Quit Playing Games” fits in 2020, but I was definitely surprised by how few Gen Zers know it. Same thing for J.Lo’s “If You Had My Love,” though she has far better songs from her oeuvre and she didn’t even perform it at the Super Bowl.
Other songs, meanwhile, remain unusually resilient and have pretty much universal recognition.

popular-hed: These are the candidates for ’90s canon: songs that have yet to fade from culture.
popular-subhed: Songs with higher than expected recognition

millennial-only.text: Why have these songs transcended generations? There’s no unifying theory. “Jump Around” still gets airplay during timeouts at sporting events. “Macarena” is still a Bar Mitzvah mainstay. “I Will Always Love You” is Whitney Houston’s magnum opus. While there are countless reasons for a song to stay culturally relevant, it's not merely a function of popularity in the year of release.
There’s another fascinating cut of this data: songs that are generational markers, approaching zero recognition by Gen Z.

millennial-hed: K-Ci and JoJo’s “All My Life” and Jewel’s “You Were Meant For Me” are widely known by Millennials, but rarely recognized by anyone else.
millennial-subhead: Songs that are approaching zero recognition among Gen Z

lollipop.text: It seems sacreligious to think that future generations will not know the significance of “All My Life” —that it’s place in history is anecdotal by anyone who happened to be alive in 1998. It’s disconcerting to think that the markers of my childhood, what felt culturally ubiquitous, will, in a couple decades, be lost in time.
But that seems to be the story of every generation: my parents went through the same existential shock when my knowledge of the ’70s was far lower than they expected.

Every parent makes a mental note of music they’ll pass down to their children—records that they hope will shape their taste for quality. That process is a marvelous filtering mechanism; a value judgement of what should be cherished versus what just happened to be popular. Billboard #1 hits mean nothing if future parents don’t tell their children, “this is good music.”
“Wild Wild West,” in many ways, might deserve to fall into obscurity.
To see how well Millennials and members of Generation Z know other ’90s hits, check out the chart below.

chart-text-hed-lollipop: The ’90s canon: songs most recognized by Gen Z
chart-text-subhed-lollipop: Recognition rates for all 1990s songs that charted in the top 5 of the Billboard Hot 100

story.text: Here we see that Father Time acts indiscriminately: song knowledge erodes over time [highlight average]. It’s why I shouldn’t be shocked when my Gen-Z colleague mentions that she's never heard “The Sign” by Ace of Base, or that teens are filming themselves listening to “Bohemian Rhapsody” for the first time. This is a normal part of the music aging process, albeit it’s sometimes faster for certain songs.

An especially somber example of this is the fate of “Wild Wild West” by Will Smith. This was the song of the summer in 1999 and pretty much was inescapable, yet it is fading far faster than any other '90s hit with comparable popularity.
Similar to “Wild Wild West”—i.e., songs with a surprising rate decline:
This list also helps us identify the '90s canon: songs that clearly have maintained their popularity and been passed on to the next generation
This list also helps us identify the '90s canon: songs that clearly have maintained their popularity and been passed on to the next generation

You might be thinking: these songs must the cream of the crop; in their prime, they were so mega-popular and pervasive that they bled into Gen Z's cultural knowledge. But remember: Gen Z knows these songs because they continued to be played, either by folks weren't sick of them or because they still had cultural cachet.
“Jump Around” is played during every timeout at sporting events. "Macarena" is still a Bar Mitzvah mainstay. "I Will Always Love You" is Whitney Houston's magnum opus.

The '90s canon question is really interesting on financial terms too. There's a site called Royalty Exchange where you can actually buy rights to a song and reap its royalties. For example, lifetime ownership of Dirty Dancing’s "(I've Had) The Time of My Life" sold for $493,500.
This is what was going through my head when looking at recognition rates: are some songs clearly transcending generations more than we'd expect?
For example, Dr. Dre's "Nuthin' But A G Thang" and Biggie's "Hypnotize" are by no means universally known by Millennials; but look how they've held up versus comparably popular songs.

Based on "Hypnotize's" popularity among Millennials, it should be a lot less popular among 20 year-olds. It's easy to think, "well Hypnotize is a classic, of course it's standing the test of time." Yet, I thought the same thing about plenty of '90s nostalgia that are just fading as we'd expect.
This speaks to, potentially, the broader hip-hop canon: Dr. Dre and Biggie's most well-known songs occupying the burgeoning category of "classic hip hop" on streaming playlists.

Here's another song for the betting market: "Poison" by Bell Biv Devoe. Again, this song is relatively obscure compared to "Baby Got Back," but look how well it's held up versus similarly popular songs.

More obscure hits essentially define Millennials. Here's the average trajectory of "Too Close" by Next, which is recognized by half of Millennials, but its knowledge decayed rapidly for the next generation

At some point, "Too Close" will be a generational marker for Millennials—it's present-day popularity is entirely driven by those who were around during its prime. This would be, in many ways, a terrible song to play at a wedding, as well as a terrible investment on Royalty Exchange.
Here's a number of songs where its knowledge is unique to Millennials
We also noticed that most of Usher's library fits this category
Biggest chance your younger co-worker doesn't know it

chart-text-subhed-proclaimers-dre: The rate of recognition, by birth year, of The Proclaimers’ I’m Gonna Be and Dr. Dre’s Nuthin’ But A G Thang

lollipop-intro.text: To see how well millennials and members of generation z know other ‘90s hits, check out the chart below.
